09-Apr-2015 12:58:28	Error occurred while running Task 'inject(2)' of type com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-variable-inject-plugin:inject.
09-Apr-2015 12:58:28	java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Malformed \uxxxx encoding.

fields.description:
I am trying to share an artifact across builds of the same plan (it's data used to optimise the build based on the last one). Bamboo will allow me to set this up: the plan has a shared artifact which is created as expected, and an Artifact Downloader task which references the artifact from the build.

I first ran the build with the Artifact Downloader task disabled, so that the plan would succeed and the artifact would be available (build 1). I then re-enabled it.

When I next ran the build (build 2), I expected that the artifact would be downloaded from build 1 as that is the most recent successful build. Instead, the logs show that Bamboo tried to download the artifact from the currently running build 2, which of course failed. I consider this a bug because at this point, build 2 is still running and cannot be considered 'successful'.
fields.summary: Taking shared artifact from the wrong build

fields.description:
*Steps to replicate*
# Create a user with full name containing some Russian characters. I created a user in this case with a name "Адриан"
# Create an IM server
# Configure a build notification to send out notification to hipchat rooms
# Run a build and wait for it to send out notification

*Observed Behaviour*
The notifications are send but the characters are replaced with a question mark. See the attached screenshot. It is worth noting that the build result summary renders the characters correctly and all encodings are checked

*Workaround*
Hover around the masked username and you can see the username of the person that triggered the build
fields.summary: IM notifications to Hipchat from Bamboo replaces Russian characters with question marks

fields.description: When the Bamboo Agent is started as a Windows Service, the environment variable such as PATH does not reflect the ones that are configured in the user profile that is running the service.
fields.summary: When Agent is started as a Windows Service, environment variable such as PATH is inaccurate

fields.description: When a script is checked as a powershell script, it should only run on Windows agent.
fields.summary: Powershell scripts should not run on non Windows agents

fields.description:
We've recently had an issue where we ran out of disk space on our bamboo server. This caused the administration.xml (in (bamboo-home/xml-data/configuration) to be empty when we tried to restart Bamboo. The logs did not give any helpful error message and I only found [this KB-article|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/Restoring+a+Bamboo+instance+after+a+crash] after I googled each of the nested exceptions. 

It would help greatly if Bamboo would tell you there's a problem with one of the config-files and not just give you a BeanCreationException.
fields.summary: Give a relevant error message if administration.xml is corrupted or empty
Release tab in deployment project does not display more than 15 releases in History

fields.description:
Since access keys are stored in user profiles, Bamboo should save and display the username of the Stash account that contains the SSH key for future references.

Example use cases may be, when an employee leaves the company and Stash profile removed, the repository would stop working in Bamboo due to removed access. With the information displayed, troubleshooting this would be easier.

Potentially, you should be able to query for a username (in database or UI) and all the linked repository of that profile can be displayed so the access can be repaired.
fields.summary: When creating a Stash linked repository, save the Stash username the access key is stored for future reference

fields.description:
*Background*
Everytime Bamboo cannot connect to a branch, an error is logged in the system logs which pollute the logs and mislead users. This is amplified in a pull request workflow as the source branch is deleted when the pull request is merged.

Error in Bamboo server logs:
{noformat}
ERROR [11-BranchDetectionBackgroundThread:pool-19-thread-1] [BranchDetectionServiceImpl] Repository error while detecting branches for plan BUILD-PLAN
{noformat}

UI error log messages
{noformat}
Build Project - Repo - Key-5511 1 : Unable to detect changes 
(com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.RepositoryException : java.lang.RuntimeException: com.atlassian.bamboo.repository.InvalidRepositoryException: Cannot determine head revision of 'ssh://git@stash.companyname.com:7999/rt/stage.git' on branch 'KEY-5511'. Branch has probably been removed.)

Occurrences: 2 
First Occurred: 05 Mar 2014, 10:17:53 AM 
Last Occurred: 05 Mar 2014, 10:19:23 AM
{noformat}

The errors create noise in the system logs.

*Possible solutions*
* Add some filter in the system errors section.
* Prevent some errors from appearing in the system error logs - in case they are misleading.
fields.summary: Deleting branches from Git/VCS cause system errors

fields.description:
The current behavior for Bamboo is to disable the plan branch when it detects the vcs branch has been deleted so that Bamboo doesn't poll for changes. They eventually get cleaned up once the inactivity period has elapsed. Please note that a '0' for inactive period actually means to disable cleanup and not to remove immediately.

However, sometimes the deleted branches get disabled but never get cleaned up even after the inactivity period has passed.
fields.summary: Deleted branches do not get cleaned up after inactivity period has passed

fields.description:
We run Bamboo with all the stock elastic image configurations disabled. We noticed a particular executable that we didn't provide on our own images (called 'Maven 3') being available as an option to the Maven Task. Looking for the cause, we found that this 'Maven 3' executable provided by three stock images when viewing the list of executables on our server:
- Windows stock image (listed 8 times)
- Ubuntu stock image (listed 8 times)
- Windows 2008 stock image (listed once)

For the repeated images, they actually linked to distinct image configurations with different AMIs and all of them were enabled. None of them included the actual current stock image on the "Image Configurations" page (which have been disabled for a long time, over many upgrades).

We would expect the these 'ghost' image configurations to not be enabled, or (more correctly), not exist at all.

It's very inconvenient having a spurious capability being the default when creating Maven Tasks, as jobs will remain queued indefinitely.
fields.summary: Past stock image configurations haunting us

fields.description:
Currently our stock images are set EXT4 as file system, which causes issues with Docker: 
* https://support.atlassian.com/browse/BSP-18172
* https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Configuring+the+Docker+task+in+Bamboo#ConfiguringtheDockertaskinBamboo-StockimagesfailtomountwhenEXT4isutilizedasafilesystem

In order to fix this and provide an out of the box solution we should apply a fix to our stock images as described here: https://github.com/docker/docker/issues/4036#issuecomment-53174208
fields.summary: Update stock Ubuntu AMI to use AUFS to provide better support for Docker

fields.description:
This request is mostly covered here, but the answer is basically "this is not supported right now" and I did not see a feature request for it: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/262527/bamboo-deployments-approved-and-broken

While the release review feature is nice, it could provide more functionality.  Right now it looks like anyone who has permissions to view the deployment project can say a release is approved or broken.  I would like the ability to restrict this to, for example, our QA department and release manager.

Additionally, it would be really nice if you could restrict the deployment process to only allow approved releases to be promoted to another environment.  For example, say I have a new release to our Development environment that was deployed automatically from our build plan.  I want the ability to have our QA team or release manager approve that build, and then, only once it has been deployed to Development and approved could it be deployed to the QA environment.  QA checks it out, approves it, and only then can it be moved into UAT, Staging, Production, etc.
fields.summary: Add functionality and permissions to the release review

fields.description:
When defining the copy pattern for a Shared Artifact in the build configuration, if you use a variable, the Artifact Download task in a deployment environment fails to download the artifact even though it says it successfully downloads.

For Example...
STEP 1 - Copy Pattern: package-${bamboo.repository.revision.number}.tgz
(The build finds it just fine and you can click on the link on the build or release page and it will download the artifact no problem!)

STEP 2 - Add an Artifact Download task to the deployment button, selecting the available shared artifact.

STEP 3 - Run the deployment and Bamboo will say that it downloaded the artifact successfully. However, download time in the log shows as 0s and the artifact is no where to be found on the agent.

STEP 4 - Once we replaced the variable in the build configuration from ${bamboo.repository.revision.number} to *, it worked.
fields.summary: Artifact Download gives false success at deployment time when using variables in Artifact Definition

fields.description:
h1. Problem:

When using the npm task in Bamboo it automatically adds a post-build cleanup task, *npm Cache Cleanup*, and re-downloads all dependencies adding unnecessary time to the deployment process.

Please allow the ability to disable npm cleanup or refine to use dependencies already downloaded when the task ran originally.
fields.summary: Improve the 'npm Cache Cleanup'

fields.description:
*Rationale*
[CMake|http://www.cmake.org] is a popular tool to generate and build projects written in C/C++, very similar to Ant, NAnt or MSBuild. CTest is a testing framework very similar to NUnit, MSTest, JUnit and so forth, and its installed alongside CMake.

*Steps*

* Install and Configure Bamboo
* Windows
** Install Windows Server 2012 R2 (agent-01)
** Install and configure an Bamboo Agent on agent-01
** Install CMake
* Linux
** Install Ubuntu 14.04 (agent-02)
** Install and configure an Bamboo Agent on agent-02
** Install CMake

Visit the Bamboo website, select the agent and view its capabilities. Note than even through CMake was installed on both agents, Bamboo does not detect it. One can add this manually, but this is tedious and error prone.  

*Expected*
Its expected that Bamboo will detect CMake as follows

* Windows
** *CMake* - C:\Program Files (x86)\CMake\bin\cmake.exe
** *CTest* - C:\Program Files (x86)\CMake\bin\ctest.exe

* Linux
** *CMake* - /usr/bin/cmake
** *CTest* - /usr/bin/ctest

It is possible to install CMake and CTest in other file paths.
fields.summary: Bamboo doesn't detect CMake

fields.description:
*Rationale*
Python is a very popular language and it is expected that Bamboo treats it like a first class citizen, similar to the JDK. The current workaround is to manually configure executables.

*Steps*

* Install and Configure Bamboo
* Install Windows Server 2012 R2 (win-agent-01)
* Install and configure an Bamboo Agent on win-agent-01
* Install Python 3.4 and Python 2.7
* Visit the Bamboo website, select the agent and view its capabilities.

Note than even through Python was installed on the agent, Bamboo does not detect it. 

*Expected*
Since Python 2.x is different than Python 3.x and there are some compatibility issues, it is expected that Bamboo will detect Python as follows:

* *Python 2.7* - C:\Python27\pyhton.exe
* *Python 2.4* - C:\Python34\pyhton.exe

It is possible to install Python in other file paths.  The expectation is that Bamboo will detect python when installed on linux agents too.
fields.summary: Bamboo doesn't detect Python 2.x or Python 3.x

fields.description:
Consider a very large codebase, more than 10 years old. Currently supported versions consist of code written in Visual Studio 2010, Visual Studio 2012 and Visual Studio 2013. Chances are the next version is going to support Visual Studio 2015.

Now consider that the repo has numerous branches, e.g. release-v4.5, release-v5.0, release-v5.1, release-v5.5, release-v6.0, release-v6.1, develop and master. Each branch has its own set of dependencies, in terms of Visual Studio, Platforms and Architectures (e.g. 32bit vs 64bit).  

Also consider that keeping this in Bamboo complicates configuration, is time consuming, error prone and doesn't allow for use of features (like build all branches).

Allow for the plan configuration to be stored in the repo, so that it can be versioned with each branch. When the repo changes, read the plan configuration (aka capabilities, steps) from the repo in order to execute it.

So the net effect is that Bamboo can still use the right agent to build the system based on its capabilities, while easing configuration by being able to build "all" branches.  While the master branch may be using Visual Studio 2015, while release-v5.5 can still use Visual Studio 2012.
fields.summary: Storing Build Repositories in Repository

fields.description:
Currenty, Bamboo clones a local copy of each Mercurial repository. When that repository needs to get checked out as part of a job, Bamboo clones the cache repository to create the working directory, pulls changes in, then updates to the revision to be built.

The larger the repository, the longer this process takes. We have an 8.75GB repository, with a 3GB working directory. This clone/pull/update process takes an hour.

Mercurial's `share` extension allows multiple working directories to share the same .hg repository. Not only can this save a tremendous amount of disk space for large repositories, it is much faster. Instead of running `clone`/`update` commands, you run the `share` command, which is almost instantaneous, regardless of the size of a repository.

You can then run the `update` command on that working directory to update the revision that needs to be built, which even for our 3GB repo takes about five minutes on a clean working directory.
fields.summary: Update Mercurial source control provider to use Mercurial's share extension when creating working directories

fields.description:
When I start the work of creating an agent, I wanted to define the a property of the agent: the bamboo-home directory. At first glance on the "http://bamboo:8085/admin/agent/addRemoteAgent.action" page, I figured I run this:
   java -Dbamboo.Home=/tai/bamboo/bamboo-agent-home -jar bamboo-agent-5.7.0.jar http://bamboo:8085/agentServer



The agent page says:
{noformat}
You may also add extra system properties like -Dbamboo.Home=... to customise the agent's home location
{noformat}

... when in fact it needs to be "bamboo.home." The H needs to be lower-case for the bamboo jar to recognize the "home" property. My suggestion is to fix the typo in the text. Not to start recognizing "...Home."
fields.summary: Typo in "Install remote agent" page makes the difference between an agent working and not working

fields.description: Currently Bamboo results only contain the commit ID but do not hang onto the repository URL. In some use cases it's important to be able to switch the repositories on the fly and Bamboo does not accommodate this well. It would be great if Bamboo could hold both the Commit ID and Repository URL so repos can be switching on the fly and rebuilds will still happen properly.
fields.summary: Improve Bamboos handling of plan reruns

bq. Configure what Bamboo should do automatically if it detects branches and pull requests in the repositories.

Such description is inaccurate as pull request detection is yet to be implemented in Bamboo

h3. Summary

Defining SSH server capabilities breaks the check out of Git repos. 

For example:

|SSH|/usr/bin/ssh|

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set up a Linked (generic) Git repo on a server with SSH access. To accomplish that, please refer to [Git on the Server - Getting Git on a Server|http://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Git-on-the-Server-Getting-Git-on-a-Server]
# Set up the SSH key pairs properly as described on [Sharing repository credentials|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Sharing+repository+credentials]
# Set up a [Git repository|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Git] to be used by Bamboo and supply the private key generated above
# Create a plan to check out source code from the repo above
# Run the Build
# Defining SSH server capabilities. For instance: |SSH|/usr/bin/ssh|

fields.description:
one of our servers reports 40k plans on admin/systemInfo.action which is a bit high. From looking at the code it seems PlanManager is calling planDao.getPlanCount(Buildable.class) which effectively lists number of Jobs, not Plans. That's misleading and should be fixed..

At the same time the page actually loads very poorly, possible has to do with 1M of build results on the instance [^2015-04-01_1123.png]
fields.summary: admin/systemInfo.action claims to list number of plans but it's actually jobs

fields.description:
It would be nice if you could keep your Bamboo configuration in version control friendly formats.  When I make a change in a binary format, I can't see what the differences are between versions.  If the Bamboo export file were in human readable format, XML for example,
then I would be able to see what changed between versions.  Since Atlassian is a system largely based off version control, it makes logical sense that the Bamboo configuration should be easily kept under version control.
fields.summary: Give the ability to export bamboo configurations in human readable, version control friendly formats

fields.description: In Bamboo test results, quarantined tests, and tests otherwise ignored (ie with {{@Ignore}} junit annotation) are lumped together, which can lead to confusion.  It would be nice to put them into two separate lists (on the same page)...unleash the UX designers on it to figure out something that makes sense.
fields.summary: Distinguish Quarantined vs Ignored test

fields.description:
h3. Bamboo requires that a specific commit be checked out when doing a full HG pull. Currently this is handled by adding the {{--rev}} parameter to the checkout process. Due to inefficiencies in how the Mercurial client handles {{-rev}} adding that parameter lengthens checkout time by up to 4x in some cases.

It would be great if Bamboo did a full checkout and then switched to the specific commit. It would eliminate a lot of time and overhead for large HG repos.
fields.summary: Improve HG checkouts by removing the initial --rev parameter

fields.description:
We have a very large application with hundreds of test assemblies. I'd like to be able to use a wildcard to specify what assemblies to run, e.g. WebMD.UnitTests.*.dll, instead of needing to specify each one.

Our current workaround is to have our build generate an NUnit project file and have the task run that.
fields.summary: Support wildcards in NUnit Runner Task

fields.description:
N.B. I only reproduced this with Post Build Commands and Success Command.
Chances are that it also applies to Pre Build Command and Failed Command.

To reproduce:

Commit the following script to the repo (or sneak it into the working dir):
{code}
#!/bin/bash
echo "The number of arguments is: $#"
a=${@}
echo "The total length of all arguments is: ${#a}: "
count=0
for var in "$@"
do
    echo "The length of argument '$var' is: ${#var}"
    (( count++ ))
    (( accum += ${#var} ))
done
echo "The counted number of arguments is: $count"
{code}

Create a job that e.g. runs a simple Script task.
In the Miscellaneous tab of the Job configuration, add a Post Build Command:
- Run Location: Run on Agent
- Success Command: ./success.sh aap noot mies
- Leave other fields unchecked/empty
- Run build

Build log:
{noformat}
build 31-Mar-2015 16:25:05  The number of arguments is: 3
build 31-Mar-2015 16:25:05  The total length of all arguments is: 13: 
build 31-Mar-2015 16:25:05  The length of argument 'aap' is: 3
build 31-Mar-2015 16:25:05  The length of argument 'noot' is: 4
build 31-Mar-2015 16:25:05  The length of argument 'mies' is: 4
build 31-Mar-2015 16:25:05  The counted number of arguments is: 3
{noformat}
All looks fine, as expected.

Now check 'Fail build if command fails' and run build again:
{noformat}
build 31-Mar-2015 16:29:24  The number of arguments is: 3
build 31-Mar-2015 16:29:24  The total length of all arguments is: 13: 
build 31-Mar-2015 16:29:24  The length of argument 'aap' is: 3
build 31-Mar-2015 16:29:24  The length of argument 'noot' is: 4
build 31-Mar-2015 16:29:24  The length of argument 'mies
build 31-Mar-2015 16:29:24  ' is: 5
build 31-Mar-2015 16:29:24  The counted number of arguments is: 3
{noformat}
There are still 3 arguments, but the 3rd one is now reported as 1 (non-printable) character longer.

Now uncheck 'Fail build if command fails', and build again:
{noformat}
build 31-Mar-2015 16:32:16  The number of arguments is: 4
build 31-Mar-2015 16:32:16  The total length of all arguments is: 13: 
build 31-Mar-2015 16:32:16  The length of argument 'aap' is: 3
build 31-Mar-2015 16:32:16  The length of argument 'noot' is: 4
build 31-Mar-2015 16:32:16  The length of argument 'mies' is: 4
build 31-Mar-2015 16:32:16  The length of argument '
build 31-Mar-2015 16:32:16  ' is: 1
build 31-Mar-2015 16:32:16  The counted number of arguments is: 4
{noformat}
The 3rd argument is restored to its original value, but we gained an extra 4th one, 1 unprintable char long.

For giggles, check 'Run in separate thread':
{noformat}
build 31-Mar-2015 16:34:45  The number of arguments is: 5
build 31-Mar-2015 16:34:45  The total length of all arguments is: 13: 
build 31-Mar-2015 16:34:45  The length of argument 'aap' is: 3
build 31-Mar-2015 16:34:45  The length of argument 'noot' is: 4
build 31-Mar-2015 16:34:45  The length of argument 'mies' is: 4
build 31-Mar-2015 16:34:45  The length of argument '
build 31-Mar-2015 16:34:45  ' is: 1
build 31-Mar-2015 16:34:45  The length of argument '
build 31-Mar-2015 16:34:45  ' is: 1
build 31-Mar-2015 16:34:45  The counted number of arguments is: 5
{noformat}
We now have 2 extra arguments.

I couldn't find a way to restore normal order.
fields.summary: Pre-Post Build Commands - corrupts last commandline parameter

fields.description:
OBRs are add-ons which bundle their dependencies such that the dependencies get installed alongside the main add-on jar. UPM was able to properly install OBRs in Bamboo 5.7.2 however it is broken in Bamboo 5.8.1. I didn't try in Bamboo 5.8.0.

Debugging into the UPM code it appears that {{org.osgi.service.obr.Resolver#getRequiredResources()}} returns an empty list where it used to return a list of dependencies. UPM also utilizes {{org.osgi.service.obr.Resolver#getOptionalResources()}} however I'm not sure if that is also broken.

I'm marking this bug as critical because there are many Bamboo Paid via Atlassian add-ons which are distributed as OBRs and this essentially means that they cannot be installed until this is fixed. (Complete list of Bamboo PvA add-ons: https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/app/bamboo/top-grossing?cost=marketplace)
fields.summary: OBR installation is broken in Bamboo 5.8.x

fields.description:
On [Using the Stash Backup Client|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Using+the+Stash+Backup+Client] documentation, in the  [How it works|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Using+Stash+DIY+Backup#UsingStashDIYBackup-Howitworks] we have:
bq. 2. Checks that all Git and database operations have completed.

Based on the information above, if running a build in Bamboo that has "{{Source Code Checkout}}" task using a Stash repository, this build should have no problems on completing the cloning task before Stash going on Maintenance mode.

However, when Stash is in Maintenance mode by [Using Stash DIY Backup|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/STASH/Using+Stash+DIY+Backup] documentation, the same Bamboo build does not happens and the following error gets thrown:
{noformat}
... Unable to detect changes. This error may have occurred due to an authentication issue with Stash. Save the repository configuration to refresh the authentication details.
(25 Mar 2015, 9:10:11 AM)
{noformat}

It would be interesting on having a feature in Bamboo that when a Repository host "{{Stash}}" is selected, prior running a "{{Source Code Checkout}}" task, Bamboo would call a REST API requesting Stash status and, in case, the same returns PAUSED, MAINTENANCE the build in Bamboo would stop and a notification message will explain appropriated the reason.
fields.summary: Prevent Bamboo source code checkout if Bitbucket Server is in maintenance mode

fields.description:
I grant you, as per BAM-5317, it's pretty nice to be able to delete multiple agents at the same time. But to delete an agent is a careful, "kid-gloves" process. It's not something I take lightly, and I want to carefully inspect what I'm doing when I do it.

So when I deleted an agent today, it prompted me, "... you are about to Permanently [SIC] remove multiple agents."

No, I'm not. I'm removing just one. Not multiple. It was a little scary to hit "OK," because how could I be sure that it's only going to take away the one I selected? Maybe it would take away more than one?

Well, after I hit OK, it did only take one agent away, but my concern is that the prompt said it was going to take away more than one.

My proof is in the attachment.
fields.summary: Warning message says, "remove multiple agents" when I'm just deleting one.

- https://bamboo.example.com/build/artifactUrlRedirect.action?planKey=PROJ-PLAN-JOB&buildNumber=1&artifactName=MyLogs

The expected behaviour is that Bamboo would detect this error and renegotiate a new secure connection to Amazon.

The workaround was to restart the Bamboo server.
fields.summary: Bamboo S3 artifact handler unable to handle SSL cert change

fields.description:
*How to reproduce:*
* Set up Bamboo against:
** *MySQL 5.1* or older 
** with the default storage engine set to MyISAM, which is not supported 

Bamboo will silently fail to create the NOTIFICATIONS table - we include errors in the log but don't expose it to the administrator in Bamboo GUI nor explain how to fix it.

The installation then continues and it looks like we have installed just fine. Bamboo will fail when the first plan is created. 

The stack trace can be found below:

*Solution:*
Set up Bamboo against a supported database and in the case of MySQL, use the supported innodb database engine.

Most customers hit that because they are trying to set up Bamboo against *MySQL v5.1* with the wrong storage engine.  MySQL provides multiple installed "engines": MyISAM and innoDB.  [MyISAM|http://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/5.7/en/myisam-storage-engine.html] is not supported by Bamboo because it does not support transactions or foreign keys.  

See https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/MySQL for options on how to specify innoDB.

Please, refer to [Supported platforms|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Supported+platforms] documentation for further information on supported databases.
fields.summary: Bamboo fails on first plan creation with MySQL 5.1 without innoDB

fields.description:
Currently, when the deployment results and logs expired, the environment information is removed from the release list. The release history is then removed from the release list in the environment details.

The environment information should be kept for future reference and consistency between release page and environment page.
fields.summary: Environment information should be kept as deployment history during expiry

fields.description: Certain Bamboo variables that have been defined in our documentation may result in a bad substitution when using SVN.  These include bamboo.planRepository.revision.number, bamboo.planRepository.lastchange.revision.number and bamboo.planRepository.username
fields.summary: Certain Bamboo variables do not resolve with bad substitution

fields.description:
h3. Replicate issue
# Please, create a *Project* / *Plan* with the following *Script* tasks:
{noformat}
DIRECTORY="ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUXVXYZ"

if [ ! -d "$DIRECTORY" ]; then
    mkdir -p "$DIRECTORY/$DIRECTORY"
    
    echo "foo" > "$DIRECTORY/$DIRECTORY/$DIRECTORY.log"
fi
{noformat}
# Please, create the following artifatc definition:
{noformat}
Name: A
Copy pattern: ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUXVXYZ/**
{noformat}
# run your build and you will be able to view the artifact generated under "{{A/ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUXVXYZ/ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUXVXYZ/ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUXVXYZ.log}}"

However, when you set up as per following you are no longer able to navigate to the "ABCDE FGHIJ.log" generated unless you fix the URL manually.
# Please, create a *Project* / *Plan* with the following *Script* tasks:
{noformat}
DIRECTORY="ABCDE FGHIJ"

if [ ! -d "$DIRECTORY" ]; then
    mkdir -p "$DIRECTORY/$DIRECTORY"
    
    echo "foo" > "$DIRECTORY/$DIRECTORY/$DIRECTORY.log"
fi
{noformat}
# Please, create the following artifatc definition:
{noformat}
Name: A
Copy pattern: ABCDE FGHIJ/**
{noformat}
fields.summary: Artifacts with spaces are not accessible by UI

fields.description: The Agent history page can get pretty big. It would be nice if it had a search box that we could type in the agent name/id, instead of turning pages.
fields.summary: Ability to search Agent history

fields.description: In the Agent history screen, it would be much helpful if we could sort the history list by its columns like 'Agent', 'Start time', 'Shutdown time'
fields.summary: Ability to sort Elastic agent usage history

fields.description:
For URL configured in seraph-config.xml, absolute URL are redirected the same way as relative urls.

Example, if the SSO portal is {{http://www.example.com}}, the resulting login URL becomes {{http://bambooURL/http://www.example.com}}.

This isn't the case for other products such as JIRA.
fields.summary: SSO portal is not redirected properly for absolute URL

fields.description:
We have seen a number of cases and had reports where builds have been triggered but they don't appear in the queue on Bamboo's "Build Activity" page.

When viewing the build, the jobs claim to be in progress but have a status of "Job has not yet been queued. Waiting for prior stages to complete." However, no prior stages are queued or building. Additionally, many agents will be sitting idle even though this build is waiting to be run (probably because it hasn't "really" been queued).

Eventually the build will go grey with a status of "Reason for not building is unknown".
fields.summary: Jobs sometimes not enqueued

fields.description:
This causes columns to be _missing_. Horizontal scrollbars are also not present but it is still scrollable.

This is due to a long value in 'Old value' column.
fields.summary: Global audit log - table cells do not wrap

fields.description:
When installing a new Bamboo 5.8.1 against an older database, the installation process may fail to create the NOTIFICAITONS table due to a issue with an  "Specified key was too long; max key length is 1000 bytes" which is only reported in the Bamboo log.  The installation will however continue - and appear to be a well installed Bamboo that you can log in to just fine. Once the first plan is created Bamboo will fail. 

An improvement for Bamboo would be to proactivly flag this in the UI, or exit the installation, until the DB is able to support the required key size.
fields.summary: Bamboo will silently fail to create NOTIFICATIONS table

fields.description:
Hi, I am learning and using SDK to develop my own tasks as a plugin for bamboo.

When I atlas-package in my helloword project, it build successfully, but there is no jar file in the target directory.

I can export the jar file from the eclipse and it works, but I can never use atlas-package to create the jar. Why the atlas-package does not work? I need help, thanks.

fields.description:
To configure a Maven 3 capability you must NOT set the path to the executable to the actual location of mvn, as Bamboo will append /bin/mvn by itself.
E.g. Maven is at /usr/bin/mvn, then you have to configure the executable path to just /usr.
See also https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/BAM-12364

The workaround seems simple, just configure the Maven capability with the shortened path.
However, when you start a Maven task, it does this:
{noformat}
simple  25-Mar-2015 08:19:54  Starting task 'Maven3 test' of type 'com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.maven:task.builder.mvn3'
command 25-Mar-2015 08:19:54  Beginning to execute external process for build 'My Project - My Plan - Default Job #4 (MYPROJ-MYPLAN-JOB1-4)'
 ... running command line: 
/usr/bin/mvn --batch-mode -Djava.io.tmpdir=/home/rene/bamboo/app/temp/MYPROJ-MYPLAN-JOB1 clean test
 ... in: /home/rene/bamboo/home/xml-data/build-dir/MYPROJ-MYPLAN-JOB1/my-app
 ... using extra environment variables:

bamboo_buildPlanName=My Project - My Plan - Default Job
bamboo_capability_system_jdk_JDK_1_7=/usr/lib/jvm/default-java
JAVA_HOME=/usr/lib/jvm/default-java
useMavenReturnCode=false

bamboo_resultsUrl=http://127.0.1.1:8085/browse/MYPROJ-MYPLAN-JOB1-4

MAVEN2_HOME=/usr

error 25-Mar-2015 08:19:54  Error: Could not find or load main class org.codehaus.plexus.classworlds.launcher.Launcher
simple  25-Mar-2015 08:19:54  Failing task since return code of [/usr/bin/mvn --batch-mode -Djava.io.tmpdir=/home/rene/bamboo/app/temp/MYPROJ-MYPLAN-JOB1 clean test] was 1 while expected 0

{noformat}
There was no M2_HOME or MAVEN2_HOME environment variable defined.
Bamboo creates them when starting the Maven build, but sets them to the *shortened* path.
So /usr instead of /usr/bin/mvn.

As a result the build fails with "Could not find or load main class org.codehaus.plexus.classworlds.launcher.Launcher" which is typical for an incorrect M2_HOME/MAVEN2_HOME (or even M3_HOME/MAVEN3_HOME, but that's another discussion).

Also tried setting the M2_HOME, MAVEN2_HOME, M3_HOME, and MAVEN3_HOME environment variables, but Bamboo just overrules M2_HOME and MAVEN2_HOME with the shortened path.

Instead of using /usr I also tried /usr/share/maven as paths, all to no avail.

A workaround is to call Maven from a normal Script Task, but then you lose the Test integration.
fields.summary: Maven task assumes incorrect M2_HOME and MAVEN2_HOME, and build fails

fields.description:
Currently Deployment Projects have a one to one releation to a specific Build Plan, so it can only utilize the artifacts form that single Build Plan. This is a problem because I have couple of Deployment Environments that need to deploy Artifacts generated from multilple build plans.


h5. NOTE
I've create this issue at the suggestion of [~jdumay]
fields.summary: Deployment project use Artifacts from multiple Build Plan's

fields.description:
Our Bamboo server is hooked up to Crowd. One time, we had some network problems between Bamboo and Crowd.

During this time, all users that tried to log into Bamboo had the following happen:
- They were given an error message about their credentials being wrong (even though they were correct).
- Their failed login count increased, even though they were using correct credentials. This made them trigger CAPTCHA prompts, which was very inconvenient to clear _en masse_.

The expected behaviour is that Bamboo would detect that the login failure is due to a communication error with Crowd rather than bad credentials and:
- show an appropriate error message to the user, and
- not increment the failed login count.
fields.summary: Do not increment failed login count if login fails due to Crowd communication error

I've attached a screen shot of the web page and the JS Error console with error. We usually have at most 2 items waiting so unfortunately I hit this a lot.
fields.summary: Error when reordering items on the build activity page

fields.description:
Over the past a while, we are being strike with several issues where clients are not able to follow our documentation on how to:
* [Bamboo upgrade guide|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+upgrade+guide]
* [Cloning a Bamboo instance|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Cloning+a+Bamboo+instance]
* [Moving Bamboo between machines|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMKB/Moving+Bamboo+between+machines]

The majority cases, users tend to follow Bamboo's export/import feature and here is where the problem starts happening. The most common issue is related to not being able to import the export generated from Bamboo.

Due to that, I have decided on creating a KB - [Upgrade/Migrate Bamboo|https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=720833273] to illustrate the steps taken to successfully perform the task with Bamboo.

So far, it has been noticed an improvement in the amount of bounces required to sort the issue raised when clients follow the steps in the KB instead of attempting on using export/import feature. Due to that, I would kindly ask you to review our documentation, please.
fields.summary: Review Bamboo documentation: Upgrade / Migrate / Clone

fields.description:
Checkouts using Bamboo and even SVNKIT take much much longer than checkouts using the svn binary installed on our build machines. 

There was a bug filed for slow checkouts: BAM-15208 which is a "won't fix", because it's based on an issue in the 3rd party library, svnkit. The bug suggested using svn export to speed up the process, however, some build plans require access to svn data/metadata, and as shown by the benchmarks on that bug, svnkit is much slower than standard svn binaries. 

Can you please create an option to just use the svn binaries on a build machine instead of svnkit for svn checkouts and updates?
fields.summary: Quicker SVN checkouts using svn binary instead of svnkit

fields.description:
Bamboo has support for SSL via APR which works fine, but the current version of tcnative (1.1.27) is vulnerable to heartbleed and CVE-2014-0224.

I was hoping 5.8 would have a more recent version of Tomcat (and APR), but it seems to be stuck on 7.0.40.

TLS 1.2 support was added in Tomcat 7.0.57 & Tomcat 8.0.15 with tcnative 1.1.32.
CVE-2014-0224 was fixed in tcnative 1.1.31.

See https://bz.apache.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=53952

This is our config we use on bamboo

<Connector port="443" protocol="org.apache.coyote.http11.Http11AprProtocol"
            maxThreads="150" SSLEnabled="true" scheme="https" secure="true"
                 keystorePass="changeit"
            clientAuth="false"
         sslEnabledProtocols="TLSv1,TLSv1.1,TLSv1.2"
         SSLCertificateFile="c:/location/cert.crt"
         SSLCertificateKeyFile="c:/location/cert.key"
         SSLCertificateChainFile="c:/ssl/intermediate.crt"
         SSLProtocol="TLSv1"
         SSLDisableCompression="true"
         SSLCipherSuite="ECDHE-RSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256:ECDHE-ECDSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256:ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384:ECDHE-ECDSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384:DHE-RSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256:DHE-DSS-AES128-GCM-SHA256:kEDH+AESGCM:ECDHE-RSA-AES128-SHA256:ECDHE-ECDSA-AES128-SHA256:ECDHE-RSA-AES128-SHA:ECDHE-ECDSA-AES128-SHA:ECDHE-RSA-AES256-SHA384:ECDHE-ECDSA-AES256-SHA384:ECDHE-RSA-AES256-SHA:ECDHE-ECDSA-AES256-SHA:DHE-RSA-AES128-SHA256:DHE-RSA-AES128-SHA:DHE-DSS-AES128-SHA256:DHE-RSA-AES256-SHA256:DHE-DSS-AES256-SHA:DHE-RSA-AES256-SHA:!aNULL:!eNULL:!EXPORT:!DES:!RC4:!3DES:!MD5:!PSK"
  />
fields.summary: Avoid heartbleed and support TLS 1.2

fields.description:
h4. Steps to reproduce
h5. Stash Repository Triggers the build
# Create a plan linked to a Stash repository
# Add a {{sleep 60}} task
# Use {{Stash Repository Triggers the build}} trigger
# Commit a change to Stash to trigger a build
# When the build start, push another commit

h6. Observations
The second build is not triggered as governed by the concurrent build rule

h5. Repository triggers the builds
# Create a plan linked to a Stash repository
# Add a {{sleep 60}} task
# Use {{Repository triggers the builds}} trigger
# Commit a change to Stash to trigger a build
# When the build start, push another commit

h6. Observations
The second build is *triggered* which does not follow the concurrent build rule

This behavior seems to be a fix for BAM-15449. However, I suspect this isn't an expected behavior as the 2nd build gets built without entering the build queue
fields.summary: Using "Repository triggers the build" instead of "stash repository triggers the build" enables "queue-build-request-until-my-plan-finishes-current-build"

fields.description:
There are missing entries in the table. We know this as viewing the history for a specific environment shows versions that don't appear on the Releases tab for the overall project.

Scrolling to the bottom of the page also shows a loader, which then disappears with no new entries appearing. This is even though, again, on the history for specific environments, we can see older entries.

Also - Expiry appears to delete the deployment history even though it says it does not. "Excludes historical deployment records". We only see 10 historical entries on the release history for a specific environment even though there has been many more. We had set Expiry to only keep latest 10 deployment logs and releases, but expected to keep the deployment history.

h4. Steps to reproduce
# Create 20 releases, Release 1-20
# Go to the list of releases in the Deployment project
# Observe that only release 6-20 is displayed
# Scroll to the bottom to the page

When scrolling to the bottom of the page, a rest API is called {{http://<bambooURL>/rest/api/latest/deploy/project/<projectID>/versions?after=true&before=false&start-index=15&max-result=15}}

The missing deployments are listed in this response.
fields.summary: Large amounts of deployment history are missing from "Releases" tab

fields.description:
Hi, writing as a developer still learning the ropes to Bamboo plugin development...

Developing with FreeMarker templates for UI for Bamboo task plugins is frustrating. There isn't much documentation, and I'm having trouble creating more complex UIs. This would be ok if using straight HTML/JavaScript was easier, but I'm not able to find anything in the way of samples, or direct documentation on taking this path.

If there is documentation on doing this and I haven't been able to find it, I'd appreciate this documentation getting better visibility. Otherwise, I'd love to see more documentation on taking this path and making more complicated task config UIs that can retrieve and set configuration data.
fields.summary: Improve Bamboo Task Development Documentation to Include Complex HTML example

fields.description:
If a build have a manual stage with a build variable, during the resumed build, bamboo provides a window to override this variable before continuing the build. This works fine on normal occassions. Now if we take a backup of an instance say version 5.3 with a build paused at the manual stage, and then use this backup for an upgrade to 5.7.x, trying to resume the build will just pop up an empty window.

In Bamboo 5.8.1, it pops up a window with a message "There is nothing to customise in this plan configuration". See the screenshot
fields.summary: Bamboo does not allow overriding a build variable from a resumed build after upgrade

fields.description:
There were multiple instances where the build/deployment job is in queued state until there is a manual intervention. 

Doesn't get listed in the build activity. All the agents are available at the time.

This happens intermittently
fields.summary: Builds are in queued state when not listing in activity

fields.description:
*Steps to replicate*
# Assume the repository is on url: http://localhost:8080/third
# Now create http://localhost:8080/third/testing/releases/rel123 and http://localhost:8080/third/testing/branches/BAM123
# In the branch configuration, change the subversion branches URL to http://localhost:8080/third/testing
# Add this regex
{code}
(releases|branches)/.*
{code}
# Now push some branches to the above directories http://localhost:8080/third/testing/branches/ as an example

We will expect that the branch will be created automatically but this is not the case and trying to create the branch from the UI, bamboo will just recognize "branches" and "releases" instead of the real branches. Therefore the regex is ignored

We have validated this regex against tools like http://www.regexplanet.com/advanced/java/index.html and this is respected when using git repository type
fields.summary: Subversion repository type does not respect the regex when creating branches

fields.description:
As described in the attached image.

Link: https://jira-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/branchinator/1068957996/JIRA%206.4.x%20branch/stable-issue%252FSW-1747-onboarding-evaluated-property
fields.summary: Wrong link in the branchinator page

fields.description:
When deleting either an environment or the whole deployment project, bamboo will sit and spin on the /deploy/config/confirmDeleteDeploymentProject.action?id=xxxxx url. Most of the times it will time out due to our web server in front of it. 

New Relic reports that the /deploy/deleteEnvironment call took 322 sec.
fields.summary: Deleting deployment environment or Project takes an excessive amount of time

fields.description: From Bamboo administration in Bamboo Cloud it's not possible to view 'System information' and 'Log settings' screens within the 'System' section. After clicking the link a 403 Forbidden error is presented.
fields.summary: 403 Frobidden error when trying to view 'System information' and 'Log settings' in Bamboo Cloud

fields.description:
While creating branch I am getting below error message

Unable to create plan branch for plan: CT-CIBVT, branch: VCS Branch [solar_1.5]. 'repository.github.useRemoteAgentCache' doesn't map to an existing object
fields.summary: Cannot create plan branch using github repository type

fields.description:
Update Bamboo image capabilities to match with the provided packages in stock AMIs.

For example, stock images comes with Ant 1.9 now and default capabilities in images still don't list this out.

PHPUnit executables location not updated too causing:
{{Unable to find executable at /usr/bin/phpunit-3.7. Will try to run it anyway.}}
fields.summary: Update Bamboo image capabilities to match with the provided packages in stock AMIs

fields.description:
When attempting to delete all the audit logs from the system, a failure occur and the message "Failed to delete all audit logs" is present.

h3. Reproduction Steps

* Login as admin
* Open Audit Logs admin/viewGlobalAuditLog.action
* See logs
* Click "Delete all" audit log button
* Confirm delete operation in popup
* Expected: all logs are removed
* Actual: message "Failed to delete all audit logs" is present

The following is logged:

{noformat}
 2015-02-27 12:44:34,392 ERROR [qtp785705372-181] [ViewGlobalAuditLogAction] org.springframework.orm.hibernate3.HibernateSystemException: Unknown entity: java.lang.String; nested exception is org.hibernate.MappingException: Unknown entity: java.lang.String
2015-02-27 12:44:34,393 ERROR [qtp785705372-181] [BambooActionSupport] Failed to delete all audit logs
{noformat}
fields.summary: Cannot delete all audit logs

fields.description:
Bamboo is currently not offered with any standard OS packaging, and makes life difficult for admins.

The attached patch provides both an RPM spec file and init script for Bamboo, just drop the atlassian-bamboo-5.8.0.tar.gz file into the SOURCES directory and build from the spec with "rpmbuild -bb atlassian-bamboo.spec".

Update the version numbers as appropriate for other versions.
fields.summary: [Patch] RPM support for Bamboo

fields.description: The build log entries in the 'Logs' tab only show the Unix epoch start date '01-Jan-1970 01:00:00' rather than the actual date of the resp. log entry. The latter are reported correctly in the log itself when accessed via the 'Download' or 'View' links, and also during the live preview on the 'Job Summary' tab, i.e. this seems to be a regression in the log parsing logic of the 'Logs' tab's code path only.
fields.summary: Build logs are incorrectly reported with the Unix epoch start date in the 'Logs' tab

fields.description:
PLEASE CLOSE: This issue was filed in error.

Configure a Bitbucket repo in Bamboo; expand Advanced options and check "Enable Repository Caching on Remote Agents" and "Fetch whole repository"

Let the build run, and cd to the build directory and run "git branch -r" to see all remote branches.

Expected: All Bitbucket branches should show up as origin branches
Actual: Only the master branch shows up
fields.summary: Bitbucket git repository cache doesn't fetch entire repository

fields.description:
We should have an option to configure the notifications at the branch level, like to be notified for builds on either Master or release branches only and exclude Feature branches.

Currently all the notifications are at Plan level and makes it difficult to fine tune this requirement. Maybe a notification scheme with an option to provide regex expression for branches would be the way to go.
fields.summary: Notification at branch level

h3. Cloud Workaround

Log a support ticket at https://support.atlassian.com and ask for your instance to be upgraded. Bamboo will be down for 10 minutes while it's upgraded so please provide a date, time and timezone for the upgrade.

h3. Server Workaround

Upgrade to Bamboo 5.8.1 available from https://www.atlassian.com/software/bamboo/download.
fields.summary: Cannot create plan branch using github repository type

fields.description:
Hello,

Our bamboo server seems to have been reset last night, as it now has an uptime of 17 hours (just under) https://seventechnology.jira.com/builds/admin/systemInfo.action

there are a lot of errors in the server log - but as this was working yesterday, am wondering if you have made any changes. Or if you can restart and or have a look into it for me.

From reading it could be a permissions issue on the server (although the server is the same one we have used continually. It could be repository permissions - again, we have not altered these.

We had a problem a long time ago with server memory, as we had put "," in our branch names and they where not expiring. But we have not done this since then, so am wondering if we have to many branches??

If you are able to assist that would be great thanks alot.

Am not sure what version the On Demand is - guessing its the latest.

Also could you include stephen.power@wearenova.co.uk in any correspondance as he will be the one in charge of fixing the issue.

Thanks

Andy
fields.summary: Bamboo elastic agents hanging

fields.description:
h4. Problem:
Bamboo does not fail builds when invalid commands are used. This can causes potential issues to go unnoticed longer than they should.
fields.summary: Bamboo does not fail on invalid commands

fields.description:
In Jenkins, I can name a "node" (aka agent) to have a "# of executors." I have not found that setting in Bamboo. We are underutilizing the CPU on our agents without that setting.

This attached screenshot of CPU usage was taken for my agent during a single build. As you can see, we are underutilizing the machine. I'd like to run another job from another build.
My goal, by the way, is not 100% CPU usage. I know it's not practical. But my goal is > 50%, anyway, and I'd rather not define another agent on the same machine which is exactly the same capabilities.

As hardware continues to scale with numbers-of-cores on the same machine and IO bandwidth continues to speed, it doesn't make sense to confine an agent to run only one thing at a time.

This was originally reported with BSP-17485.
fields.summary: Two executors on an agent

fields.description: Please provide the option to separate mail notification logging from Bamboo logs, as it is the case for JIRA.
fields.summary: Separate mail logging from application logs

fields.description:
We had a case where a deployment project was deploying to the wrong server due to the remote agent failing to use the server's new IP address. The DNS entry had a short (10 minute) TTL and was changed several hours before the deployment ran. 

My understanding is that Java's DNS caching behaviour may be to cache lookups forever (at least until the agent is restarted).

The expected behaviour is that the agent will not cache the DNS lookup for longer than the TTL specified in the DNS record.
fields.summary: Remote agents failing to pick up DNS changes

fields.description:
Administration menu items are normally highlighted when the menu link is clicked.  Some of the menu items are not being highlighted when clicked, making it hard to see which page is currently viewed on the admin screen.

* Application Links
* Find new add-ons
* Application Navigator
* Manage add-ons
* Purchased add-ons
* Atlassian Support Tools
fields.summary: Administration menu items not highlighted when clicked

fields.description:
*Steps to Replicate*

# Integrate JIRA with Stash and Bamboo
# Create a JIRA issue with an ampersand (&) in the issue summary
# Now create a branch with the JIRA issue key
# This branch will be created in Stash and picked in Bamboo with the character escaped. 
# Now try to link the branch with the JIRA issue as explained in this [guide|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Using+plan+branches#Usingplanbranches-jiraissues].
# The issue summary will then be added as a branch description
# Now in Bamboo, try to save the branch and it will fail as per the screenshot
fields.summary: Branches linked to JIRA issues can not be saved if they contain special characters

fields.description:
Hi

The feature from BAM-13268 allows me to create, say:
 - a deploy project to deploy QA branch to QA server
 - a deploy project to deploy staging branch to staging server

But I would love to have the ability to create a single deploy project and do:
 - use the deploy environment QA to deploy to QA server
 - use the deploy environment staging  to deploy to staging server

Currently all environment configs within the same deploy project are using the same plan branch.
fields.summary: Add support to plan branches and deployment environments
